❌ Another broken promise ❌

Looks like the Conservatives’ promise on regional funding meant as much as their promise not to raise taxes 🧐

Levelling Up is impossible if you take money out of people’s pockets and out of the communities that need it most

https://t.co/Hr8SBYka5P

Less than 30% of ‘Homes for Ukraine’ applicants have had visas issued.

Fewer than *3 in 100* have actually arrived in 🇬🇧

Nearly a month since scheme was announced

People need help now. Government must cut unnecessary bureaucracy and get people to safety
https://t.co/Begy5WZNsA

- North will be particularly hard hit by rising living costs
- Gov support insufficient + poorly targeted
- Risks "setting levelling up back years"

The days when Levelling Up was the government's top priority feel a long time ago 🤷🏻‍♀️

From @CentreProPolicy https://t.co/n0G1dnHlcJ

“In reality, we’re just answering calls from people and telling them to wait. It’s utter chaos and it’s just getting worse.”

https://t.co/CmFUx3ls5r

This is grim, but was sadly a risk from the moment the government set up a DIY scheme where refugees had to advertise themselves on social media.

Charities have called the scheme “Tinder for sex traffickers”.

The government needs to get a grip.

https://t.co/K6sTGszH4K

🚌 More than half the areas that were eligible for new money for buses won’t get a penny.

“The government claimed areas that failed to get the cash had not shown ‘sufficient ambition’”

The only people lacking ambition for Levelling Up are Tory ministers

https://t.co/f2XP4UdXMG

Ukrainians fleeing war need help *now*.

But excessive bureaucracy is preventing them reaching sanctuary in the UK.

And it is squandering the amazing generosity of Brits who have offered to open their homes.

The government needs to get a grip.

https://t.co/AFDYHh0VJV

It’s a relief that the government has finally realised a DIY, tinder-style scheme for refugees isn’t good enough.

But precious time has been wasted. People need help urgently.

The government cannot go on wasting the generosity of people who want to help

https://t.co/nI54KX2psn

Michael Gove seems to be (for some reason 🤷🏻‍♀️) Boris Johnson’s go-to guy in a crisis.

But the DIY refugee scheme he has set up is leaving desperate 🇺🇦 Ukrainians to fend for themselves, and squandering the generosity of 🇬🇧 Brits who want to help.

‘Homes for Ukraine’ needs fixing https://t.co/gigLCvceRw

Ask any two government ministers what Levelling Up means and you’ll get two different answers.

For me Levelling Up is about getting good jobs and investment back into towns, and money back into people’s pockets.

✍️ I wrote about this for @TheHouseMag

https://t.co/NduJ7YpWGJ

The government’s 12 Levelling Up ‘missions’ won’t reduce regional inequality - says respected @instituteforgov.

5️⃣ aren’t ambitious enough
3️⃣ aren’t realistic
2️⃣ are too narrow

Well worth a read👇

We can do so much better 🌹

https://t.co/GS2ZFHM2oY

🇺🇦 The PM couldn’t say today if a *single* Ukrainian refugee has arrived in the UK under @michaelgove’s scheme, announced nearly 3 weeks ago

Despite 200,000 Brits signing up to be sponsors

The government are wasting people’s generosity and failing desperate people needing help https://t.co/1FvPHnzBZS

How underwhelming is your flagship policy when you have to literally pay people to be nice about it? 😬

But seriously…

Ministers can’t find any new money for Levelling Up, but they can spend over £100,000 of our money to boast about themselves 🤨

https://t.co/JLnsohsQAe

Instead of a DIY scheme where sponsors and refugees have to find each other on social media, the government needs to take charge of matching people.

This is a serious humanitarian crisis, not tinder for refugees.

People have stepped up. The government needs to do the same.

Ministers gave no thought to key details before it was announced and people are suffering as a result.

Gov’t needs to cut the unnecessary bureaucracy and speed up the processing of visas. 

Even the Refugees Minister admitted this morning the form takes too long to fill out.

We now know that only 1 in 100 of the offers by people to open their homes to Ukrainian refugees, has been taken up.

This is scandalous. We’re wasting the amazing generosity that British people have shown. 

https://t.co/dgmzHo5srV

Unnecessary bureaucracy must be cut to get people here quicker.

And the DIY Homes for Ukraine scheme is forcing desperate people to advertise themselves on social media. The government needs to match sponsors and refugees.

People have stepped up. The government must do the same

People have showed amazing kindness in offering their homes to people in need, but the government is squandering that generosity.

✍️ @YvetteCooperMP and I have written to Priti Patel and Michael Gove asking why it is taking so long for Ukrainian refugees to reach the UK 🇺🇦🇬🇧 https://t.co/i0LFQfem6J

“We’re facing the humiliating prospect of the huge generosity of the British public going unmatched, due to Home Office bureaucracy”

Even people in government are saying this now 👆🏼

⁦People have stepped up to help. The government needs to do its job

https://t.co/B4JubUPtK7

The system for funding local councils is too complicated, Michael Gove says.

Wait until he hears who is in charge of it all. 

He’s gonna be livid.

https://t.co/Pvwa3hNMPc

Fantastic to visit Barnet as we approach local elections 🗳

Last week @RishiSunak chose not to help families struggling with the cost of living.

With a clear plan to cut energy bills and get money back into people’s pockets, it’s clear that only Labour is on your side 🌹 https://t.co/3fbnZDHYz2

It’s over a week since the first refugees were supposed to arrive under Michael Gove’s ‘Homes for Ukraine’ scheme.

The government won’t tell us if anybody has arrived yet.

Generous Brits have stepped up. The government must do the same.

https://t.co/mxbIDpOTTM

The P&O workers are human beings, not expenses to be discarded like numbers on a balance sheet.

The Government should be backing them and taking real action to save their jobs and livelihoods.

#bbcqt https://t.co/Zcn3qIEdst

This Chancellor has chosen to protect the profits of oil and gas companies over the needs of families.

There’s a perfect storm on the cost of living but it’s clear the one thing the UK can least afford is a Tory Government.

#bbcqt https://t.co/ypnhqumkMB

This is horrendous.

How can we be asking pregnant refugees for a visa for their unborn baby before we give them safety?

Scrap unnecessary bureaucracy. Sort the matching process.

People here have stepped up. The government needs to do the same.

https://t.co/KMyBH4pjP2

The Chancellor says ‘judge me by my actions’. On that we agree.

He can’t pretend to be cutting taxes when he’s doing the opposite.

And he can’t pretend to be levelling up when he’s stripping money out of people’s pockets and communities, and taking funding out of our regions.

Rishi Sunak could have announced more money for our most disadvantaged communities.

But we heard nothing 🤐

In fact he’s now refusing to guarantee we’ll get back funding that we’ve lost - something we were promised in the Tory manifesto.

https://t.co/KWzUzvf8Sw

You can’t level up when you’re taking money out of people’s pockets.

That’s money taken out of our high streets and local economies.

Promising tax cuts in 2 years’ time doesn’t help when he’s hiking taxes in less than 2 weeks.

We’ve been told over and over that Levelling Up is the government’s number one priority.

How many times did Rishi Sunak mention it in his #SpringStatement?

Answer: 0️⃣

And it gets worse…

A brief 🧵

Seriously though… Levelling Up is meant to be this government’s top priority and Rishi Sunak had *nothing* to say on it.

Page after page of documents just published contain nothing new.

This is not good enough.
Searching for any mention of Levelling Up in Rishi Sunak’s #SpringStatement https://t.co/tyxN7vyf3U

High inflation and Tory tax rises have created a crisis for families and businesses. The Chancellor has to recognise this today.

Back Labour plans for a windfall tax on oil and gas producers and cut up to £600 off energy bills. https://t.co/Dsx6EzGfk3

This👇 isn’t good enough.

The first Ukrainian refugees were supposed to arrive in the UK yesterday.

The government are going to squander people’s amazing generosity if they don’t get their act together https://t.co/wHfOFfO7uO

The Homes for Ukraine scheme is mired in excessive bureaucracy with no thought  given to the desperate situation facing Ukrainian families fleeing Russian aggression. This is a serious crisis, not online dating. Government needs to grip this urgently.

https://t.co/JQPksX1EMr

This is the nonsense of levelling up. While Michael Gove talks about a “Medici-style renaissance” his government is moving good jobs out of our towns and taking money out of people’s pockets. 

https://t.co/MI77aAU2HT

Sometimes, for the safety of family members who are detained, families aren’t able to take this approach. So today I’m thinking of all those who are still being held, both in and out of the public eye, including Morad Tahbaz, who is still being held in Iran.

It’s amazing to see these two lovely families reunited at last. They were helped by so many people along the way but it was their brave, spirited campaign that ensured Nazanin and Anoosheh were not forgotten. I hope they now get the space they need #NazaninIsFree #AnooshehIsFree https://t.co/2RhO73Lnu2

The thousands of people stepping up to help shows Britain at its best. 

To see that generosity realised we need to move much more quickly to bring Ukrainians here.

It's right that we have checks but the Govt must cut the excessive bureaucracy. https://t.co/fIFYSVuVoZ

All across this country people are coming forward to help Ukrainians in need.

But there is still much work the Govt needs to do to turn this ambition into a plan.

I have written to Michael Gove with actions that should be undertaken urgently to help make this scheme work. https://t.co/kj8d7uYHn2

It's heart-warming to see so many British people coming forward with offers of help for Ukrainians. 

But all we appear to have is a DIY asylum scheme where sponsors and refugees have to find each other.

The Govt needs to play its part. https://t.co/mz7JyGK71H

24 hours after he toured the TV studios offering safe haven to Ukrainian refugees  the Secretary of State still hasn’t picked up the phone to councils and charities, all existing bureaucratic hurdles remain in place and the website isn’t working. This is desperate. https://t.co/UNQJsTf91t

We welcome this scheme but urgently need more detail.

Are we really asking desperate Ukrainians and British sponsors to find each other online, dating app-style?

#Ridge https://t.co/JzhSIhSbx3

The pandemic showed that in a crisis we can step up as a country. We stand ready to do that again. So far ministers have behaved like these are ordinary times. But these are extraordinary times and we need extraordinary measures.
And they must engage councils and charities. They will be at the heart of making this scheme work and they know what can be done, but incredibly they haven’t been asked yet.

Ministers must reduce all unnecessary bureaucracy facing desperate Ukrainians. People fleeing Putin cannot be expected to provide excessive documentation and wait months in freezing conditions while it is verified.
- This group of refugees is quite unlike those we are used to. There will be many children and older people. What’s being done to find school places and healthcare for them?

- Why is there no provision for unaccompanied children?
- What additional support will local government receive, and will sponsoring organisations and housing providers also be awarded £350?
- Will families have access to Universal Credit for housing after their sponsorship ends?

- How many people are we expecting through the scheme? 
- How long will it take to get them to the UK?
- Do willing Brits really have to have a prior connection to a Ukrainian family in order to sponsor them?

We’ve known for weeks that generous Brits want to help Ukrainians fleeing war. The problem has been government dragging its feet. It’s welcome that this scheme is finally starting but we still need far more urgency and too many questions remain unanswered⬇️

Charities say it could take two years for Ukrainian refugees to reach the UK under Michael Gove’s sponsorship scheme which he hasn’t even launched yet. These are desperate women,  children and elderly people. Is this what No. 10 considers ‘very generous’? https://t.co/BPFWpbb4gm
My inbox is full of offers of help from British families. They are so much better than their government.

This is ridiculous. While Ministers squabble women and children are being bombed. The Government needs to get its act together and establish a humanitarian route based on biometric checks at the border, not a visa process that takes months.

https://t.co/qB2lHkUqnj

We would freeze business rates next year saving businesses thousands of pounds before replacing with a fairer system, to protect our high streets and put money back in people's pockets.
Our Climate Investment Pledge will grow the jobs of the future. Last week I saw in Grimsby the impact the right investment can have: https://t.co/WphWWC9TDH

We would also deliver Labour’s plan to create new apprenticeship opportunities, which would see 100,000 more apprenticeships available to young people this year. Our education recovery plan stands as a testament to our commitment to the young people who make this country.

Where the Conservatives have overseen one third of children leaving primary school without the basic skills to get on - Labour's would ensure no young person leaves education without the skills they need to thrive in a modern economy.

Labour would rebuild the foundations of our local economies, and allow people the chance to have not just jobs, but good jobs again. We have ambitious plans to buy, make and sell more in British towns to make local economies boom.

Is this it? The Govt's 12 missions for Levelling Up are nothing more than 12 admissions of failure. We can do so much better than this. Labour have a plan to build our local economies & give people the choices & chances they deserve. Here’s how⬇️ https://t.co/jFo83bMrSh

https://t.co/jFo83bMrSh

Our coastal and industrial towns once powered country. Now our young people have to leave town to find opportunities. That isn’t fair. We deserve a proper level of investment from our Government. Our people have the ambition. Why hasn’t the Government?

2/ Thriving high streets, powered by support for our local businesses. 3/ Towns and villages that are better connected to our jobs and family. 4/ Hand decision making back from Westminster to local communities 5/ Safe town centres with proper neighbourhood policing.

To truly deliver on the levelling-up promise, the Government must meet the ambitions people have for our own communities. Specifically this means: 1/ Good jobs across the country so young people don’t have to get out to get on.
A Labour Government would give young people choices & chances, with a £28bn investment each year in green energy to create the jobs of the future in our coastal & industrial towns.
People across the country are grappling with a cost of living crisis – they aren’t asking for a few new tiers of Govt. We need to tilt the balance of our country back in favour of those who built it

They are talking about 2030. But what are they doing now? People in towns across this country need opportunities and good jobs TODAY. It is only by putting money back in people’s pockets, that we will start to see local economies thrive.

Some of these announcements were actually first announced by Gordon Brown. Even Theresa May’s Industrial Strategy has been rebranded as Levelling Up in Gove’s plan. Britain deserves better than reheated ideas. It needs new leadership.  https://t.co/wBMlkMCPTS

Boris Johnson's answer to our communities calling for change is to shuffle the deckchairs - tinkering with government structures and recycled announcements. This is not what was promised. We deserve far more ambition than this. https://t.co/tSSJKsOLzW

The Prime Minister is hopelessly distracted trying to save his own skin. It is not good enough to give out rehashed pots of money to just 20 places. The Govt have got to put money back into people’s pockets, deliver good jobs, and match the ambitions we have for own areas. https://t.co/rkJJNytn7H

Four years after the appalling Grenfell tragedy, hundreds of thousands of people are still trapped in unsafe housing, millions more are caught up in the wider crisis and 72 families are waiting for justice. No more delays. We need a credible plan to fix this, in full.

His own department can’t even process the applications they have and is off-track to replace Grenfell style cladding by half a decade. To be fair he accepted this - but when will it be fixed? He can’t say.
What will be done about the many, many buildings that have other fire safety defects, apart from cladding? Most buildings have both. You cannot make a building half safe.
Leaseholders who have already paid out won’t get their money back. How many more are likely to be charged before he comes up with a plan? (He can’t say).
If they don’t pay up who does? Will he raid his levelling up budget instead? Or take money away from affordable and social housing?
It’s now clear Gove doesn’t have permission from the Treasury to raise taxes on developers. So how will he get them to pay up? He can’t say.

7/ The Prime Minister has had 18 months to prepare for this. We are now days away from the end of a chaotic and mismanaged withdrawal.  

The eyes of the world are on today’s meeting. The PM has to make it count

6/ A strategy for protecting our collective security. 

The government needs to set out how it will work with our partners to prevent Afghanistan becoming a safe haven for international terrorism and posing a direct threat to our national security

5/ A collective approach to dealing with the Taliban. 

If we can take common steps based on shared principles, we can maximise our leverage. 

For example, the G7 should ensure we have frozen all the billions in assets held by the Afghan Government and Central Bank

4/ Humanitarian support to Afghans, including food, water and medicines. 18 million people are already dependent on aid. The government’s offer on aid barely undoes its own drastic cuts.

3/ A global agreement to support Afghan refugees. Neighbouring countries need to be supported to keep border crossings open and all countries should do their part to meet the scale of the challenge.

10/ No more reviews - Green Book review; Business Rates review; National Infrastructure Strategy review. It’s time to start investing now.

9/ If you want to level up the Red Wall, you have to level up the people in them. We need investment in skills, schools and measures to tackle what is on course to be the highest level of child poverty in 60 years.

8/ At the same time, they’re putting money into roads, potholes and freezing fuel duty for the 10th year in a row. Car usage is now the biggest contributor to greenhouse gas emissions. Where is the investment in buses and trains?

7/ He mentioned an £800m Carbon Capture and Storage Project creating 6k jobs. This is similar to the £1bn project Cameron proposed and then cancelled after four years at huge cost to the companies involved. Why would we believe this will actually happen?
6/ Sunak was curiously silent on the one thing the red wall most needs - good jobs. 750 Treasury jobs are moving North, but which ones? Is the power to make decisions moving too?

5/ Michael Gove said this morning the government won’t publish an impact assessment of their proposed EU trade deal. It’s becoming increasingly clear they don’t actually know if £600bn is a promise they can keep.
4/ The promises on business rates and broadband are welcome but they don't add up to anything like £600bn. There is a reason for this and it’s the one word the Chancellor didn’t say once - Brexit.

3/ City regions are getting a (welcome) £4.2bn. But how will that money get out of the cities and into towns? What is the plan for Workington or Hastings that aren’t in city regions? Why has the government written them off weeks after promising massive investment?

2/ This is even more important because of coronavirus. Directing money to the NHS but ignoring social care will mean more older people having to go to hospital for care or stranded at home, especially in Red Wall areas.

Second - treat retail as the hugely important industry it is.

The role of government is to facilitate and enable local decision making and action. Where national organisations are involved, they must engage locally rather than from a desk many miles away.

We know what works. Good local leadership and a joined up plan which includes local people. A diverse local population with the disposable income to sustain a mix of retail outlets. Good jobs, good transport links, affordable housing.

Our towns are each unique. A one-size-fits-all approach will fail. Strategic responses to high street decline shouldn't follow a template which results in dozens of identikit towns which all look the same.

The good news is that some good work is taking place. Many Labour councils are keenly aware of this challenge and are trying to meet it. As I've always said, people in towns are the best resource we have. Empowering and resourcing them is important.

Many of our towns are ageing rapidly. They are thus being stripped of the spending power required to sustain a vibrant mix of high street retailers. Which is one of the reasons why I've been passionately advocating for our towns.
If the local population is ageing and/or struggling to make ends meet, the high street responds accordingly by replacing flagship retailers with discount stores.

I have spoken for many years about declining high streets in our towns. A declining high street is a visible symbol of a town's relative prosperity and people feel that decline very deeply. @BBCPanorama

6) Most disgracefully, Boris has u-turned on the promises made to child refugees and EU citizens - who've made the UK their home. New provisions mean the watchdog can be axed at the stroke of a pen by Ministers.

4) The trade deal process will now be conducted in secret, with the EU Parliament having more power and scrutiny than British MPs. What happened to taking back control?

If last night showed anything it showed there may be a majority across the House for a customs union and a form of soft Brexit. But as we narrow down the options, next week will be harder than this. We owe it to each other to recognise this and find a way through

There are better democratic methods, like Citizen’s Assemblies, that would give people a voice in this process and brings us together instead of continuing to tear us apart (see me and Stella Creasy on it here: https://t.co/cb5Bb2V5YV)

I have huge reservations about a second referendum (as I did about the first one). I set them out here https://t.co/yCEtj9UYSK These serious problems remain unanswered, and they cannot just be wished away

Other MPs who are sceptical about other models such as Common Market 2.0 abstained so as to allow as many alternatives to no deal as possible through to the next stages. They aren’t cowardly or sitting on the fence. It’s a compromise and I’m grateful to them for it

That’s also why, despite my huge reservations about a second referendum, I abstained rather than vote against it last night. We don’t have the luxury of ruling out options at this stage. We’ve been voting things down for three years and we are staring down the barrel of no deal

No deal is the worst possible outcome for the country. It would destroy jobs, tear up the Good Friday Agreement and dismantle employment rights and environmental standards that we’ve fought for over the last century. But it is the legal default if we don’t agree on an alternative
Last night I voted for every option that would allow a close economic relationship with the EU after we leave. I only voted against one option - to leave without a deal at all

Last night MPs were asked for our views on Brexit. There’s lots of talk on here about betrayal including from colleagues. I wish they would stop. Most of us are trying in good faith to resolve a mess created by a small group of people which has become a national crisis

This morning I told 5 Live that if Parliament didn’t start to compromise we would strengthen the Prime Minister’s hand and allow her to double down on her my way or the highway approach that is breaking this country. Collectively, we didn’t, and we have. This is not leadership

As we vote today, MPs should allow as broad a debate as possible by voting as many solutions to this #Brexit crisis through - and so avoid a disastrous No Deal. It’s time to find common ground. https://t.co/EAES7sN3Kv
